description:
I came here on a weekday during lunch time around 12:15pm with my coworkers. There's both inside and outside seating available; we chose to sit outside because it was a nice sunny day. The waitress promptly seated us and the food came out in a timely manner.

I got the Chicken Parmesan -- the chicken wasn't dry, the portion was a good size, and it was pretty tasty overall! Priced at $25, I think it's a bit too expensive. But if you're willing to drop that much money, I'd say go for it.

I heard the Golden Gate All-Natural Burger from here is pretty good. If I come back next time, that's what I'll order!
author: Wesley S.

description:
Hope you're not in a hurry. After 45-50 minutes we finally asked where the hell was our lunch?
Food was good once we got it but, I shouldn't have to notice that all the tables that filled up AFTER I got there, are getting food before me. The table that sat next to us and late in the lunch rush, got their food in less than 10 minutes. 
I blame the waitress because YOU know we ordered food. YOU know we've been here for 45 minutes. Why haven't YOU gone to see what happened to our food and BTW I think YOU lost my ticket. And then I see similar orders coming out of the kitchen for the next 10 minutes after we call out this wait. She lost the ticket or never put it in...(POS system would solve this issue.)
I would actually feel better about the experience, because we're all human, but then you don't even fucking discount the food? They paid for the one glass of wine I had and that was it. Bad customer service and I will NOT be back.
author: Sherry W.

description:
Came for Friday lunch with some coworkers around noon, and while the outdoor seating was already full, the inside was almost completely empty and we were able to get seated immediately.

For a lunch spot, this place is definitely on the pricey side. I bet it's popular for business lunches or a company sponsored meal. You can get sandwiches and burgers for around $15, and entrees hover around the $30 mark. 

Luckily I wasn't too hungry, so I ordered a bowl of their New England Seafood Chowder ($12.99). It was the perfect amount of food for me, though I did feel that the price was on the high end for how much soup I actually got. Food-wise, it was pretty standard.

One of my coworkers also ordered doughnuts from dessert menu to share, and that was pretty good. It was very easily shareable as each doughnut was small.

My coworkers really like this spot though, and especially the burger here, so I guess that's the thing to get?
author: Dianna H.

description: Really great steakhouse. If you're in the area check them out. Fast service and the waitress was friendly and helpful. The price was about what you would pay at any restaurant in San Francisco. We will definitely be coming back here the next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Ernesto M.

description:
I've been a long time lurker on Yelp, so when I stopped at this restaurant earlier this year, I took the advice of Yelpers and ordered things that were recommended. Verdict? Expensive for portion size, and nothing really stood out, unfortunately. Shared plates were appetizer size but not appetizer cost (~$11 / each).2/5

Portabello mushroom fries: These were meaty as portbello mushroom are. 3/5

Mini pot pies: These tasted normal, kinda like your Marie Callender pies. 3/5

Bacon: As a self-identified bacon addict, these were pretty good-- chewy, peppery, savory and slightly sweet. 4/5

Everyone on Yelp raves about the "alleyway," and I guess it's kind of nice, with the outdoor seating and heaters so that eating outside is possible during the winter. Still though, it seems obvious that it was meant to be a trash disposal alley and not a planned one with restaurants on both sides and a wide walking area, so that takes away from the ambiance for me. 2.5/5
author: Nicole H.

description:
This place is located in the Belden alley, it's a bit hard to find at first, but if you look for the sign with the big blue B, it's the restaurant right next to that with the giant ladle.

My friends and I started off the night with Happy Hour, where we got a bunch of The Sharks. The drink itself was pretty good, it tasted a bit like an Arnold Palmer, but alcoholic and made with earl grey tea. You couldn't taste the alcohol too easily but it was decently strong.

We had a variety of the appetizers and shared plates, ranging from the cheesy bread (pretty good, tastes like cheesy bread with tomato sauce), to the sampler (of the bunch, the rangoon and the mushroom fries were probably the best, the deviled eggs and the bacon were just so-so), to various items such as the tater tots (passable, a little spongy), and the chips (literally chips with a bacony dip).

The vegetarian strudel was actually pretty good, and probably my favorite dish of the night. The tomato sauce went very well with the other vegetables in the strudel and balanced everything out quite beautifully.

I would pass on the pecan salad, it was a bit boring.

Overall a fun place to chat, eat, dine and relax!
author: Tyler T.

description:
Came here for a grad dinner with several friends. It is a really cool spot in an alleyway and has a great vibe, but the food was nothing special.

For appetizers, I ordered the Portobello Mushroom Fries and Cheddar Cheese & Green Onion Tater Tots. The Tater Tots were too big and not too crispy so it ended up tasting like a bunch of potato. They tasted a little better with the ketchup and the vinaigrette. I was excited to try the mushroom fries and was a little disappointed in those as well. It was hard to eat because it was hard to bite off the mushroom, and the mushroom itself was not that tasty. The outside was good and crispy and the ranch dipping sauce was on another level. Seems to be their specialty. 

For the main course, I ordered the Vegetarian Strudel (the only vegetarian option on the menu) and was again a little disappointed, based on the hype that I saw about this dish on Yelp. The tomato bisque was good, but was nothing special, compared to other bisques that I've had. The asparagus was well prepared and tasted great with the bisque. The mushrooms were easily the highlight of this dish - very gooey and soft and well flavored. The strudel itself was super flaky and crispy on the outside, but a bit too filling on the inside. It was warm and tasty, and complimented nicely with the bisque.

Overall, although the food was decent, it was not worth the price so will definitely not be coming here anytime soon in the future.
author: Sampath D.

description: I went to Sauce for dinner and was not disappointed. The chili was really good and had a little spiciness to it, which I loved. I also ordered the steak with truffle fries and shared the doughnuts dessert. All were tasty and filling, though on the pricier side for sure.
author: Lillian B.

description:
I came here for lunch with my friends and we were seated pretty quick.   They have TVs here, so on game days, it's a good place to catch a game.  We ended up ordering the fries and the devil eggs.  There were 4 eggs per order,  The fries came with two different sauces, but i thought the appetizers were ok.  

For lunch we each ordered the brussels sprout salad. which had bacon bites and a light sauce. I thought this was pretty good and the portion of it was just right.   The pumpkin seeds went every well with salad, but there was very little bacon in this salad.   

Overall, i do think the food is average.  They do have indoor and outdoor seating.  However, the service here was ok, i wasn't really greeted when i first walked in and the hostess didn't really acknowledge me.   i'm not sure will i come back.
author: Belinda C.

description:
I came here for dinner with my friends a few times. I liked the atmosphere and the food. The service was okay but who cares as long as it is not horrible. For me, the food is more important than the service :) 

Here are my recommendations: 

- Shrimp and lobster salad (my favorite!) 
- Vegetarian strudel 

Bon appetite!
author: Jen P.

description:
Cool spot with nice atmosphere hidden in belden alleyway. I came here after work and usually drool over the yelp pictures and preplan my order but fair warning they have a changing menu so most of it is different. 

I sat at the bar service was great and they were able to give me good recomendations. I started with a light but delicous order of beef carpaccio and followed up with an order of cheesy tots. The drinks were the strongest mixed iv had in the city and a good price. The carpaccio was tasty and the tots scored pots for having northwest tillamook cheddar but were a bit starchy on the inside. 

Lots of interesting drinks, great service and music in an upscale atmosphere, and a wide ever changing menu of food.
author: Sean G.

description:
Great spot for after work drinks and food! It's super easy to make reservations, and it doesn't get too crowded. You can request to sit outdoors, which is absolutely beautiful with string lights. Plenty of heat lamps to keep you warm, or just order more drink ;] 

Must try: Sampler platter, and Mac & Cheese!
author: Lisa L.

description:
3.5 stars. This place is really loud for lunch -definitely not a place for business lunch. 

I had the large wild boar chili - decent. Can be a bit thicker. Pretty filling. Good flavors. 

My friend had the crab roll which she loves - maybe worth a try.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I can't say I really wanted to come here tonight. It was after a 3 hour show and I still have 3/4 of an amazing pizza left in the fridge. However my partner was hungry now. It's better to feed him than deal with the demons that come out of you don't 

We were seated in Derek's station . How lucky for us to find such a good waiter this late at night.We started with the homemade Tater tots  then went on to the devils eggs topped with a beautiful piece of bacon. For dinner we had the wild boar chili, that was delicious, as well as the bacon wrapped meatloaf meatballs over mashed potatoes. Smelling the truffle french fries from the table next to us we had to give those a try as well. I think the chef should finish them off with black truffle salt from Sur La Table

The interior was inviting them to join. Lots of friendly people having a great time at the tables around us. I want to say a special thank you to Derek and the rest of the team for the end to a fun evening!
author: Tony C.

description: Super delicious food! Really great tapas, they have some regular sized plates too. The drink menu was super cool, the cocktails were original and definitely got us buzzed. The location was awesome, it looks like there's a lot to do for a night out in the city. The Kale Salad was BOMB btw!! Def would come back again, also heard there was a bed and breakfast attached to it at the other location!! I would LOVE to do that one time (if I won the lotto lol)
author: Melody C.

description:
Dinner review. American.

3 - Bacon wrapped meatloaf
3 - Braised beef short rib pot roast 
2 - Burger
4 - Fries
4 - Cinnamon donuts

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
Came here for lunch with a co-worker.  It was pretty crowded, but we were able to get seated right away.  Service was fast as well.  Waitress was friendly and attentive.  Considering how busy it was, I'm surprised how great the service was here.

What we ordered:

Appetizer:  Deviled Eggs

Entrees each:
- Tomato Bisque with white truffle grilled cheese
- Golden Gate All Natural Burger w/ Bacon and american cheese, chipotle aioli and ketchup

Everything was pretty awesome.  I'd recommend coming in to try this spot out.  I was discouraged at first when I saw the crowd -- but after getting seated so quickly, and the fast service that followed, I was pleased!  Was not disappointed.
author: Cat D.

description:
Got the tater tots (not your regular store bought tater tots so I guess that's a good thing? Still TBD on this one...), pecan and dried fig salad (pretty good) and clam chowder. The chowder was tasty, but it seemed lukewarm when it came out; I like my food piping hot.

Overall, place wasn't bad. I guess it's what you expect on Belden Place.
author: Cal C.

description:
Came here with a friend a few weekends ago for dinner. Not super crowded, though it was the Financial District on a Saturday night, which is typically less busy compared to the weekdays. We got seated right away (love how they have hooks for your purses at each table!). 

Our waitress was really courteous, she checked on us at least three times before we ordered (a little overbearing, but I do give her props for being on top of it). She answered all our questions and gave us choices (for example, putting the salad dressing on the side). I was expecting to see burgers on the menu (since that's the category it falls under on Yelp), but didn't find any on the menu. We still decided to go ahead and ordered four items to share: portobello mushroom fries, ham hock tater tots, beef tenderloin carpaccio and a large bowl of chili.

Portobello mushroom fries - not what we expected, but don't regret ordering it. A first read of the item made us think it was regular, potato french fries with pieces of mushroom shredded on the side, but it was actual mushrooms cut like a wedge fry! It was well breaded on the outside and had good body to it as we sliced into each piece. It was paired with a ranch dip. The taste is still vivid in my memory!

I was really looking forward to the ham hock tater tots. They were good, though not what I expected and not in a good way. I'm used to cylinder-shaped tater tots with a golden brown crisp on the outside and potato-y inside as if in the insides were diced. The ones at Sauce were kinda thick and had more of a french fry texture inside (like a smashed potato). Came with ketchup and I believe a salsa verde dip. It was good while hot, but once they cooled down I was getting over them.

The beef tenderloin carpaccio, thinly sliced meat (six pieces), topped with chopped egg, deviled egg, arugula dijon aioli, caper and red onion (plus five baguette pieces). I had a hard time figuring out what flavor was the most prominent in this one, but I did like it.

The chili was really filling! It was topped off with a dollop of melted cheese, a dollop of sour cream, chopped onions and cilantro. Had a good spice to it, though not spicy to the point where I needed to grab a drink of water. 

I also ordered the Hibiscus El'Diablo or, as it's described in the menu, the margarita's evil cousin. It comes with tequila, ginger beer and hibiscus flavor. Definitely felt the booze after a few sips, I liked it! I've had this place bookmarked for awhile, glad I finally came around to trying it. The restaurant's in this alley that you wouldn't expect to find in FiDi neighboring other restaurants that look just as good. Seems like a great area for happy hour after work!
author: Jamey P.

description:
This place really stood out for me as they offer a ton of awesome stuff and the staff did a fantastic job working with our table. I really think that this place offers a ton of variety with a lot of fantastic dishes. Our table did quite a lot of the shareable plates, and gotta say they were damn good, especially the meatloaf dish they offer. 

I really don't have anything negative to say about the place; we eventually ordered entrees and I really enjoyed the skirt steak with fries. Our waitress was on the ball, and so were the others helping her. 

Honestly, very impressed with everything. Dem bacon and eggs, doe.
author: Ben S.

description: Went after work on a Friday, wasn't too crowded so they seated all of us 15 outside where there are also heaters. It's definitely a more casual, laid back place, not fancy. The street with the lights is very cute. Rose bottles ranged from $16 to $18. Sliders, and other happy hour food options were $5. Service was great. We had a good time!
author: Emily A.

description:
I was so disappointed by this place- super expensive, small portions, and nothing amazing. 

My friends and I came here at 5:30pm on a Tuesday. It was pretty empty, and we sat inside at a high table because they don't have any regular tables, which was annoying to begin with. The happy hour deal was a glass of red (tempranillo) and glass of white (sauv blanc). This is not a Spanish place, so I'm really confused why tempranillo was the red white. It's not a widely liked wine, I feel like they should have picked pinot noir or cabernet.

We started with the cheesy bread, which tasted like it came from a box. Huge pieces of bread with random cheese on it, definitely nothing gourmet . Then, my friend and I split the brussels sprout salad and the salmon. Both were fine, but nothing special. The salmon was SO small. Probably 2 ounces. The salad it came with had a weird horseradish dressing, not something a lot of people like, so I'm not sure why they picked that.

After all that food, we were obviously still hungry because the portions were so tiny, so we got the tater tots. These were pretty good, but not regular tots and there weren't that many.

Overall, I would not come back here. The food was way too expensive for the portion size.
author: Jenna G.

description: Service was good, we got seated immediately on a Friday evening (bad sign??), and the food was mediocre... I think this place is good for a one off, but I don't think I'd go out of my way to visit again.
author: Amanda T.

description:
You know, for a place named Sauce, I'm surprised that they aren't only serving tons of saucy pasta dishes. 

The menu is broad, covering appetizers, sandwiches, salads, and full-fledged entrees. Considering that it's located in Belden Place, which has been called the French Quarter of SF, its menu is pure Americana. I see why it's the place of choice for both people on their days off, and workers; the service is very friendly and fast, while the food is high quality and easy to eat. Come to think of it, most of it is the kind of stuff you can throw on a grill real fast, or assemble without much fuss. If you like to eat without getting sloppy, they serve many dishes that fall into that category.

I came with a group of 8 from work.  We'd made reservations a few days before with no problems, and were seated promptly. Our server was very kind about explaining ingredients to some of our party, who had dietary restrictions like soy and vegetarianism. If you're allergic to soy, their fries are made with a combination of oils that included vegetable oil, so you might want to pass on that. If you aren't allergic and just have a preference for other toppings like cheese, they offer American, cheddar, and jack cheeses, along with tortilla chips, seasoned fries, or salad. Ultimately, herd mentality led six of us to choose the Golden Gate Burger with fries, while one sprung for the veggie burger and another went for the chicken sandwich.

The burger is good, as it's juicy and has few vegetables aside from lettuce (you want veggies? That's what salad is for.) Go for cheddar or jack over American cheese. While there's absolutely nothing wrong with a slice of melty American, I think the tang of either would better complement the sauce. No complaints here, because we all downed the burgers. The salad is heavy on the arugula, so if wild spring mix is your thing, you'll like the salad. If you're like me and prefer all things greasy, the seasoned french fries are the way to go. I think they must toss the fries in baking soda or parboil before frying because they develop a nicely textured crunch that results from a potato slurry coating the outside of each stick (thanks to J. Kenji Lopez-Alt for teaching me that.) It results in a satisfying side.

Back to the service -- we'd overpaid by about 10% and the guy helping us said it was fine and he'd consider it his gratuity. Um, no! I wish I'd gotten his name, because he deserved a way bigger tip (which we left) for helping us navigate food allergies, last minute drink decisions, and juggling us on top of the otherwise busy restaurant. I appreciated the heads up on when our food would be out, and the fact that he managed to put the right plate down in front of everyone, no questions asked. If you have the time to take a leisurely lunch, definitely make the trek from your air conditioned office for their comfy outdoor seating.
author: Gwen W.

description: Fun to find this place down an alley - you feel so accomplished and "in the know" to have arrived here. Food is a step above typical pub food and wine and drink options are good. Can see this place being great for the outdoor area but the outdoor seating is limited.
author: Julie N.

description:
Pretty good lunch spot.  Came here with a friend today right before the lunch crowds came in.  There were tons of sandwiches, salads and entree options.  

It was a hard choice but I decided to try the shrimp Caesar salad.

The portion was not that big, it honestly felt more like an appetizer size but it was tasty. 

I ordered an iced tea which tasted like coffee. 

If I ever go back I'd probably opt for more bar food vs healthy salad. 

My friend got the bloody mary which would have been a better drink option!
author: Kimberly L.

description:
The food was amazing! The restaurant was a little noisy but they can't control who the crowd is. The decor was cute, intimate, and comfy. Our server was attentive, friendly and made great recommendations. The little restaurant alley it was located in was also very charming with clever graffiti wall art. 
We had the clam chowder which had real clam shells in it and was served with a triton fork. The broth was so flavorful and not too thick. We also shared the Parmesan chicken which came with fresh paperdelle pasta in a buttery sauce and spinach sautéed with garlic. The star of the show was the garlic bread, which was freshest soft on the inside with a crunchy exterior married with a buttery biscuit....so good.
Overall an awesome experience and would highly recommend this gem of a find!
author: Drew G.

description: Omg.. love the food and our server is awesome. Halloween staff theme is wonder women except our server I hope I remember his name right but Wonder Steve.  Wonder Steve is great and funny. Every single dish was sooooo goood. My fav was the portobello fries, Mac and cheese and of course bowl of sweet brown sugar bacon. I must come back for their other dishes and a few of their cocktails when I'm not driving.
author: Christy V.

description:
This was a last minute dinner find in on my niece's San Francisco graduation trip. They wanted comfort food and Sauce had some great reviews. It was also nice that we were able to make reservations as it was a Friday night and we didn't know how busy it would be.

The atmosphere of the restaurant was very chill and relaxed. The menu was simple with 3 - 6 options in each section. We were definitely able to get our comfort food fix. I really enjoyed that they took the traditional foods and gave them an elevated twist. My personal favorites were the cheddar cheese & green onion tatter tots and the New England clam chowder. However I've got to say, everything we ordered was excellent.

I could definitely see myself becoming a regular patron of Sauce if I lived in the area. It was great find. I will be making a return visit the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Mari S.

description: Had some time to kill in the area so stopped in for a drink and a munchie.  Everything was very good and served with a pleasant smile and accommodating service.  Will def stop back in again.
author: C.C. G.

description: I really enjoyed Sauce (Belden Place). We made an Opentable reservation on a Saturday night around 5:30 and were surprised (and slightly concerned) that we found the restaurant pretty empty. This concern was definitely unnecessary because everything we ate (chicken, steak, soup, etc.) was excellent. The service was also great. I think the menu has changed a bit since I last went, but I will definitely go back soon!
author: Kristin A.

description: Good place for a drink after work, but I wouldn't come back for the food. We came here for a going-away party for a former work colleague. I ordered the honey side car and I thought it was way too sweet, which was probably intentional and I was warned; but I don't think any drink should be that sweet (except maybe something like port or limoncello). So, I stuck to mojitos for the rest of the night to chase down the celebratory shots that were going around. Those were good and shots were nicely chilled. I found the food to be just ok. We ordered a number of appetizer platters (deviled eggs, zucchini fries, meat balls, mac 'n cheese, fries) and nothing really stood out. I'm giving this place a 4, though, because the service was very good and they handled our rowdiness well.
author: Jeanne R.

description: FOOD POISONING - went here last night around midnight. Boyfriend and I split the clam chowder. As soon as we got back to our hotel room we were both bed-ridden with stomach cramps and soon were both in the bathroom violently vomiting. Definitely won't be going back.
author: Bess H.

description: My go to for late night noms since I've moved to SF - when everything else is closed near the office and I forgot dinner, it's a great place to get a hearty meal! They're wine pourings are generous, and after a few times of going there, the baked mac and cheese is a staple. The other items on the menu are not extraordinary, but this place is reliable and I know I'll be back!
author: Marites S.

description: Really awesome. I ate the tomato bisque and a Manhattan on the rocks. Service is on point and very quick service. I'm glad I saw this while walking around
author: Karan L.

description: I have been a few times now to Sauce at Belden place and I have enjoyed it each time. My first time I went for Restaurant Week in 2017, and everything was so great we came back a few more times. The ambiance is intimate. I personally love the outdoor seating at Belden. The staff is always friendly, and eager to help with menu choices! Last time I was there I split the cheddar cheese and onion tater tots -- these are a lot bigger than regular tater tots! And a little different texture than I am accustomed to, but still good. We also share the chili, it is a huge portion! And very tasty.  I had the salmon which was delicious and crispy! Love the crispy outside.
author: Gina B.

description:
I remember this place being so much better! 

Came in for lunch. Ordered the cobb and a side of fries, 

The fries were not cooked completely so they were a bit firm, the cobb had to have at least 1 cup of red onion. I also had to walk up to the bar for a refill on my water. Waiter never checked in with us except when he took our order. And my last point....not trying to be mean here, but I can't not say it as it seriously affected my experience...The host kept walking past my table and everything he did, I got an aggressive whiff of his body odor (as I was eating). 

Certainly wasn't worth it, and won't be coming  back.
author: L V.

description:
This was a very nice place that was open late. We showed up at 11pm on a Saturday and stayed until 12:30am. Our server was great, broke down some of the plates for us and was informative and pleasant... also no mistakes with our order or bill (always a plus). We got the following:

Social Platter:
   The bowl of bacon was really tasty, with a light sweet glaze over it. Was not crazy of how it paired up with the apple sauce.
   The Rangoon's were amazing! So tasty and light. By far best thing on plate.
   The Portabela mushroom fries were tasty. Would have preferred a crispier batter but tasty. I thought this was French fries with mushrooms over it but no, it's sliced deep fried battered mushrooms lol.
   The Deviled eggs were tasty with a piece of their bacon on it.

Beet Salad:
    Salad was light and full of flavor enjoyed it a lot, was not crazy about the huge chunk of goat cheese they threw on top but I just moved it aside. 

Chicken Parmesan:
   It was fried chicken breast very tasty, with the cheese melted over the sauce instead of over the chicken. I'll admit, I liked it more this way. It allowed for the cheese to stay hot and melted over the sauce instead of hardening and cooling over the chicken. My favorite part of the plate though was the salad that came on the side. Very lemony and brought a breath of lightness to a plate that normally is very heavy.

PB&J
   A very interesting take on an old classic. It's basically an ice cream sandwich with a light layer of PB&J. It was very tasty and caught myself talking about how interesting a take it was... I liked it, not amazing but enjoyed it.

We were there for a late dinner and halfway through our meal saw another guest eating a delicious looking burger with onion rings I think (no burger was on the menu). We asked our server and he said that there is an unlisted burger item you can order that is normally on the lunch menu. So a heads up if you want a burger.

All in all very tasty, we enjoyed our night but it was not a panty dropper. I don't see myself coming back... I will try another spot but glad I tried this place.
author: David T.

description:
My co-workers and I were looking for a new lunch spot and we found ourselves at Sauce - Belden. Don't get upset if you can't find this place. It's tucked away in an alley between Kearny and Montgomery street.

This place has a cute outdoor patio and indoor seating as well. Today was a nice day so we decided to sit outside and it was beautiful. I ordered the mini chicken pot pies for $10.99 - made with organic chicken, English peas and carrots with gravy. The crust was cooked to perfection - light and not too flaky. The dish came with 4 mini pot pies and I thought it was just the right amount of food for me. I also ordered the cucumber and basil gimlet - made with Deep Eddy vodka, fresh basil, English cucumber and lime juice. Such a refreshing drink to have in the middle of the day!

Two of my friends ordered the Golden Gate All Natural Burger that came with seasoned fries and salad - all for $15.99. My other friend ordered the Sauce Classic Tomato Bisqu with the white truffled grilled cheese for $10.99. Got a chance to try their food and thought it was all very tasty. The burger was juicy and the salad was fresh. The tomato bisqu was creamy and loved the white truffled grilled cheese. Not something I've had before but will definitely come back for that one again.
author: Tina M.

description:
Atmosphere and service were good with a cool vibe, but the food and alcohol was just okay. It is a great happy hour spot though, with affordable slider+cocktail combination! 
Portobello mushroom fries was interesting...the fried coating texture is kind of unusual?? Ham hock tater tots were okay.
author: Ya K.

description: Tasty and delicious foods! Upscale versions of classic dishes. We were lucky to get a table for 7 without reservations and the food was appropriate for all, including the kids, everyone was happy. In particular, between the table we ordered almost everything on the menu, and every dessert. Each dish was fantastic. It's impossible to say what was the best, but in my top 3 was definitely the pb&j dessert.
author: Lara S.

description:
me and my girlfriend came here on a windy Sunday evening.
patio was closed, it was cold.
we ordered crab rangoon, bacon wrapped mini meatloaf and Rosie's Chicken Parmesan.
crab rangoon was pretty good, the sauce was good.
the mini bacon meatloaf and chicken parmesan were okay.
ordinary restaurant.
author: Rudy H.

description: Super cute, chill and sassy place. Food was pretty good and my waitress was so sweet and awesome! Great customer service!! A+ I would definitely recommend this place
author: Anie S.

description:
I've come here on two occasions (both with reservations) - once during lunch, once during dinner. 

On both occasions, my best friend and I experienced slower than average service (although the restaurant wasn't packed). However, the food makes up for most of it. 

We had our first lobster roll here and we were informed that they make the bread in house! We both loooove bread and agreed that it was so good we probably could have eaten it alone. 

We also got the sampler platter and the portobello fries stood out the most. We'd order them alone next time :-) 

We've tried the chicken Parmesan and steak here but they're not as memorable. 

Lobster roll, portobello fries and a bowl of bacon (if you have a large group to share it with)!
author: Julie L.

description:
I like Belden Alley, but some of the restaurants in this alley just doesn't do it for me...like Sauce.

Pros:

1) Nice outdoor seating (but I still preferred indoor).
2) Lively atmosphere
3) Good for large groups

Cons:

1) Mediocre food
2) Unimpressed menu
3) Slow service
4) Dirty utensil

Overall, I'm glad I lagged to try this place because it wasn't worth it.
author: Owie N.

description:
2.5. Gal behind the bar was very nice and professional. Came in for lunch today and ordered the portobello fries, the chop salad with chicken and bacon and egg, the tomato bisque soup and the donuts. Just Meh. Seriously, nothing special and all dishes were VERY bland. If you read other review, they seem to say the same thing. The ranch dressing is supposed to be very good here- more sour cream based and thicker- and they tend to use this sauce in many of their dishes. It's bland and has no taste. Nothing more to add- just bland. It accompanied the portobello fries- which by the way were very breaded and had a overbearing taste of flour batter/oil taste. ( this was the best item ordered of the lot) the salad was so bland I didn't eat it- I tried doctoring it up with salt and pepper and even asked for another type of dressing to get some flavor out of it- but it didn't work. The portion was great and your could easily split it. The waitress took it off my bill which was very nice. The soup was tasteless as well and came with a ton of bread to dip it with. Can't say anything else about it. The donuts were basically mini croissants - not donut consistency, which were overly dry.  sad about this- was really looking forward to them. 
This restaurant is down an alley with many other restaurants- unfortunately I don't think I would come here again- staff was very nice , facility was clean but the food is just mediocre.
author: Eva C.

description:
Wow, this restaurant really blew me away.  Casual cafe atmosphere but really excellent food.  The clam chowder was very buttery and the best I've ever had.  The waiter says the chef is from Boston and takes pride in the chowder.  I believe him.

The lobster bisque was very good also, as well as the mushroom fries and bacon deviled eggs.
author: Rob L.

description:
We have dined here several times and continue to return when we are in town.
The lobster roll has been replaced with the dungenous crab roll. It is amazing! Highly recommend it. Limited menu, but everything we have tried has been excellent. 
Friendly staff and great drinks. Recommend the keg wine and any of the signature cocktails. 
Good ambiance and friendly service.
author: Rob F.

description:
So we arrived in San Francisco pretty late. We checked into the Omni and went down to the bar. The kitchen had closed. We asked the bartender if there was somewhere good we could go for food after we get drinks. Several people at the bar heard this and there was a consensus that Sauce had better drinks than the Omni, and had excellent food. After a quick check on Yelp, we saw they were open and reportedly awesome, and we made our way over with a little quick walk.

This place was surprisingly small. There's more room for everything in Florida. The atmosphere was really nice. The staff were warm and inviting. There was a nice mixed crowd of people and everyone looked happy. 

We ordered a couple of drinks and they were delicious and hit the spot after the long flight. We ordered several items of food and they were all excellent. This place is a great place to hit if it's later in the night. I will likely return next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Alden K.

description: Place was delicious from the appetizer, to the salad, to the entree. Everything was fresh and made like someone back in that kitchen really cared about the food they were preparing. Great place.
author: B B.

description:
Tucked away in Belden Alley, you must ask for outdoor seating if you dine at Sauce! I believe their social plates (meant to share) are more popular than their entrees, so pick a few and enjoy them with your company.

- Ham Hock Tater Tots ($10.99): these were alright, but I did like the sauces that it comes with
it! 
- Mini Chicken Pot Pies ($10.99): not only were these so freaking cute, they were delicious!
- Chocolate Truffle: I don't normally eat chocolate, but this dish sounded so good we had to order it. NO REGRETS! Each bite was so heavenly, I almost converted to a chocolate lover.

Great food presentation and attentive service. Will be back!
author: Christine S.

description:
Belden place is this super cute alleyway with a few different restaurants. In the middle is Sauce! A couple of my friends and I came here for happy hour and to watch the Warrior's game that night.

We ordered some drinks, 2 sampler/appetizer platters ($35 each) and 4 orders of sliders (2 sliders/$4.50). The sampler platter was cool because you get to try a few different items: bacon, deviled eggs, portabello mushroom fries, and crab rangoons. We split each platter with about 4 people and each had 1 slider, and we were all content!

My favorite thing in the sampler platter was definitely the mushroom fries that everyone raves about! They're pretty crunchy on the outside, and the dipping sauce is really creamy. The crab rangoons were good, though I couldn't tell they were "dungeness crab rangoons". Also the dipping sauce tasted like apple sauce... Hmmm! The deviled eggs were something different because usually I don't even like deviled eggs, but I enjoyed having one here. The thick cut bacon was also cut into bite size pieces and had a caramelized glaze. Yum!

The sliders are interesting because they come with a little cube of patty meat, cheese, and mashes potatoes on top. I've never seen mashed potatoes on a slider!

As for the ambiance, there's plenty of tvs here but it doesn't seem like the best place to watch the game... Everyone is pretty quiet so we felt weird when we were cheering for the dubs! We ended up going to a bar nearby afterwards.
author: Tara A.

description:
If 7x7, eater, or SF weekly wants to start a 10 worst San Francisco burger list....this would be the place to start.

Where to begin? From frozen patties that were undercooked in the middle, to a wonder bread bun served stone cold, tortilla chips with ranch dressing ( what? Am I in 5th grade again?). Oh yeah 2 dollar up charge for a small serving of fries.

Sauce is just a mess. One beer, one burger, one side of fries $28!

Go to Louie's instead
Go to Spruce instead
Go to Super Duper
Go to Rove Kitchen

Just don't go to sauce expecting a good burger
author: David G.

description:
I had high hopes coming into Sauce. All the pictures on Yelp were making my mouth water. My friends and I came on Tuesday night and it wasn't packed. We had the happy hour sliders and they were yummy. The Tater Tots tasted fine, nothing too special. Not sure what the 2 sauces were but for sure one was ketchup. We also ordered the appetizer sampler. Kind of disappointed in the Portabello fries. Can't really describe what I mean. I guess I expected a different taste. The deviled eggs were a little plain. Crab rangoon is always good. And the bowl of bacon was a little special. It's like honey rubbed bacon. Interesting taste. For my entree, since I'm not a big eater, I opted for the Mac n Cheese. It was nice and hot. I liked the shell macaroni they used. The cheese wasn't as melty as I would have liked. 

Things not related to food: Service was great. Our waitress was very attentive and regularly checked on our table. I liked that under the table, there were bag hooks. Perfect for the ladies. There is outdoor seating, however, I didn't like how there were so many flies flying around. It wouldn't be a pleasant dining experience with flies constantly bothering you.

All in all, I feel like Sauce just has really good presentation. Taste wise, it wasn't anything special.
author: Benita M.

description:
Was in town for work and came here for the steak.  It was heaven!  The spinach and potatoes that it came with were perfect too.

My only complaint was that it took a really long time to get our dinner.

Staff was friendly + helpful with wine recommendations.
author: Erika T.

description:
Maybe I went on an off night but my group and I were not impressed. 

We sat outside under their heat lamps, staff were friendly but the food wasn't very good. Ordered the tots, they were OK just a very small portion, brussel sprout salad which was gross cuz it was just drowned in dressing, spinach and kale greens which we all liked the best, and the happy hour sliders. They're two small grilled chicken sliders with mashed potatoes and gravy on it... Ya won't order those again. We also ordered the donuts for dessert but they weren't cooked through.

Will I go back? Nope.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Let me start by saying our server Aaron was pretty great. The 2 stars is not based on him at all. I might have given 3 or 4 if I hadn't ordered what I did.

I ordered the Roasted Corn and Heirloom Tomato Salad, and in retrospect maybe I shouldn't be as mad as I am because the title is accurate and descriptive. It was literally that -- $15 for an ear or two of corn, sliced lengthwise, with small, sad pieces of heirloom tomato, red onion shavings, and a corn puree. The corn puree was interesting and tasted good, but needed to be more of it. The whole thing was just bland and monochromatic on the white plate. I expected there to be lettuce, so I guess my bad for not checking, but seriously does anyone really want to eat that much corn?? Just not appetizing or filling at all. Thankfully I ordered some fries to go with it so I could fill up on something.

This was the second time I've been, and the first time I ordered a sandwich and it was OK. Nothing crazy special. Both times the service was excellent.
author: Nikki G.

description:
This place is great for shareables! I met someone for lunch at Sauce we shared the Bacon & Eggs, the tomato bisque & grilled cheese, and one other thing, I can't remember.  But everything was lovely, very easy to share (they brought an extra cup for the soup!) and we enjoyed our lunch.

My only hesitation is with the service.  I've been here one other time for happy hour, I wonder if it's because this place is long and skinny so it's hard to walk around, and people like to stand in the middle of everything during happy hour in SF, but it seems like it's hard to get anyone's attention if you need something.  Although, I received the same spotty service around lunchtime and the place was nearly empty.
author: Jessika S.

description:
As my wife and I trudged into our hotel after a three hour reroute/delay on our flight and over twelve hours after we left the east coast, all we could think of was getting some comfort food ASAP.  Our lovely concierge (see my review for The Galleria Park hotel) took one look at us and directed us here.

We started with drinks... Because... Y'know.  My sidecar was fantastic and my wife's Moscow mule equally so.

We chose the appetizer sampler and the scallops.  Let me just state that if anyone ever tells me that a bowl of bacon isn't a reasonable appetizer then I'll tell them they are crazy and direct them here for reeducation.

The deviled eggs with bacon wedges were amazing.

The bacon wrapped scallops were phenomenal.

The bowl of bacon was... Well... as fantastic as a bowl of brown sugar encrusted bacon sounds like it should be.

The mushroom fries were awesome.

The lobster rangoon (what's the plural of rangoon?  Rangoons?) were a revelation.

Five stars across the board.  The quality of the service was second only to the quality of the food and drinks.

Kudos to everyone at Sauce.  You made the end of a long travel day, and the beginning of our vacation, turn from dreariness to exuberant joyfulness.
author: Ali T.

description:
I appreciate that they serve food late but like the 4 other restaurants I've tried on Belden, the food we tried just misses the mark.

Though definitely the best of the Belden Alley bunch, the prices and the flavors just didn't match up for me. 

My fries were so dry they felt hollow and more charred than flavorful. The mac and cheese is a little too rich... and I love a rich mac and cheese but I came in feeling like I was "starving" and had to quit after just a few bites because it was just too much. 

We sat at the bar and service was there but gave off a very neutral to unfriendly vibe. Very robotic and somewhere between slow and 'maybe they forgot about us?'.

It's very possible that I just didn't pick the right items-and they do have a commendably diverse menu. There's definitely other stuff I'd come back to try on main entree menu and I think Sauce could be just the right fit for a casual sit down lunch in this area.
author: Candice G.

description:
I thought this place was okay. The atmosphere was pretty nice and the food was okay.  The service wasn't that great. My friend ordered the sausage roll and they brought out the lobster roll instead. I would have gladly taken it but they brought it back to the kitchen when we corrected them. I had to flag the waiter over several times in the beginning when I was waiting on my friend when I needed something. Also, she ordered a root beer and the server didn't bring it by until 40 minutes later. She didn't charge for the drink, but in general, service wasn't that great.

I found the food to be meh. The mini pot pies were pretty good. My brussels sprouts salad was just okay. The deviled eggs with bacon were exactly that. She said her sausage roll was good but too much bread. 

Also, it was chilly inside. It would have been warmer to be outside next to the space heater than inside with the draft from the open door. We weren't even near the door and still felt it. In terms of volume, we were there around lunch time and it was definitely noisy.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Came here for lunch and had the rainbow kale salad. It was very tasty and I really liked the fennel on top. It was definitely a bit small considering the price, but it was good nonetheless.

Service was great, and the wait was not long at all. This alley is really unique!
author: Emily H.

description:
Tucked away right in the middle of other restaurants and in an alley, Sauce exudes a great spot to meet up, grab drinks and take your comfort on homely food to grub on.

I loved the lobster roll!  The roll was toasted perfectly right and buttered up to goodness.  Have generous lobster pieces smacked right in between, and each bite is to savor over.  The clean, velvety wine complemented well with the lobster roll.  

Outside dining is an option and adds to the charm of dining in between an alley.

Staff was attentive and nice. 

You can Sauce me up here, anytime!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Came here for lunch.  Tried the Brussels Sprout Salad, Scallop N'Bacon appetizer and the Bacon Burger (I know, not super healthy).  Everything was really well made and tasty.  Service was fast and friendly.  The burger was juicy, although a bit too big.  The sprout salad was absolutely delicious.  The scallops were probably the weakest of the three, but still plenty good.

It is a bit pricey, but if you're careful about what you order it won't break the bank.
author: Denis S.

description:
The Belden location can be found nestled in a quiet alley way on Belden Street. I was surprised to find a variety of small, vibrant restaurants were also located around this area. San Francisco never ceases to impress me. It's like San Francisco's little kept secret!

Came in with pretty high expectations given the high ratings on Yelp. Usually known for their social plates and generous portions, the significant and I thought it would be a good idea to share our dishes for the night. 

With regard to the social plates, we tried the MINI CHICKEN POT PIES ($10.99), which incorporated Rosie's Organic Chicken, English Peas & Carrots with Gravy and the GRILLED AKAUSHI KOBE SIRLOIN STEAK ($27.99) - dried Black Mission Fig, Point Reyes Blue Cheese, Pumpkin Seeds & Arugula Salad Russet Potato Skins & Demi for our Entree. 

The Pot Pies were unlike any other typical pot pie with a plain exterior crust filled with chicken and pea bits. Long and behold, the mastered art of all pot pies, right here at Sauce! Shredded (organic) chicken exterior molded in a small ball to enclose the flavored peas, carrots, and gravy that's inside. Easy enough to take it all in one bite! Unfortunately, this was the only noteworthy meal of the night. This social plate came with 4 golf-ball sized pies, enough to feed one person on a diet. I, personally, don't believe in "diets" other than the "see-food diet", so this barely filled my hearty tummy. 

The Sirloin Steak, yet another eye-opener for me as I was expecting a normal slab of steak and was surprised to see about six small square-cut slices of meat for a rather hefty price. In addition, the plate came with a mere 5 pieces of potato skins. WTF! I would've been less upset had this been a social plate, however, this was what they defined as an Entree. Not cool, Sauce, not cool at all.

Didn't dig the scanty portions and left this restaurant hungry and unsatisfied. 

Since I am a believer in second chances, I'm willing to give this place another try with a bigger party in hopes for a better dining experience.

+ Indoor and outdoor seating available.
+ Reservations highly recommended.
+ This venue charges an extra 2% tax for Health Care Fees for their employees in addition to the county's 8.50% tax rate. (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/28/healthy-sf_n_2567446.html).
author: Kate T.

description: My wife and I dropped by this afternoon for a beer/shot kind of thing. Really like the atmosphere and the patio outside. The little corridor outside is a good photo op. Steff had the "Shark" cocktail, it rocked. I ordered a "shot" of tequila and got "neat" pretty much. A bartender after my heart. Didn't eat. Didn't have to.
author: Brian S.

description:
Came to Sauce on my recent trip to San Francisco on the recommendation of a bartender (a girl's best friend). I loved, loved, loved this place. 

Location - down a cute little alley. I feel that the location adds to the ambiance of this location. You feel like your going to a secluded, little restaurant that no one else knows about. And when I'm on vacation - I want to go where the locals go. 

Service - just fine. Our server as quiet but he kept the drinks coming and for that I'm thankful. 

Food - the FOOD! So good. We started with the Ham Hock Tater Tots. They were yummy and a great indicator of what was to come. I ordered the Grilled Akaushi Kobe Sirloin Steak. The steak was cooked perfectly to order. The demi glaze sauce was perfectly seasoned - I think I'm going to carry a bottle of it around. The potatoes served with it were amazing. They were flavored well - crispy yet soft in the middle. Nom. Nom. I also had bites of my friend's food (yes, I'm that friend). Clam Chowder - delicious. Rosie's Organic Chicken Parmesan - delicious. Braised Beef Short Rib Stroganoff - delicious. See the trend? Everything was good. 

I definitely recommend this location if you're in the area. There isn't much else that was open late in the area. But truth be told, even if there were a ton of open restaurants, I would still go to Sauce.
author: Christina P.

description:
This has got to be the one dinner where everyone I came with had the same exact cravings! 

Crave has other locations but we went to the one in the alley where it is lined up with three or four other restaurants. This is where each restaurant serves up their best contender to steal you away to their restaurant and forget the others! However, Sauce won out the competition. 

FOOD: Like I said, we all craved the same thing on a cold SF evening.. So main entree of the night all across the table, tomato soup w/ grilled cheese! It was delicious! Tomato soup was savory, sour but so nicely paired with their soft but toasted grilled cheese triangle points! Such a comfort meal. Although, we weren't able to try anything else because everyone got the same thing.. So rule of thumb, sharing is caring right? So don't order the same entree if there are other good meals you guys can swap a bite with! HOWEVER, we did get deviled eggs w/ bacon, Mac and cheese, and Hamhock tots for appetizers! All of which were very yummy and well picked. 

SERVICE: They were friendly. They had a good laugh when they realized we all ordered the same thing. Good service nonetheless. 

Next time I'm in the alley, I look forward to seeing who sells their restaurant the best once again.
author: Julienne D.

description:
Appetizer are amazing here. Great happy hour place and small bites! I come here a lot with my friends when we just want a nice sit down with great snacks.

We usually order:
Portobello Mushroom Fries (MUST ORDER, super good, crispy and great flavors, one of my fave)
Ham Hock Tater Tots (MUST ORDER, comes to two sauces)
Beef Tenderloin Carpaccio (this is okay, good with wine, comes with bread)
Crispy Wontons (okay good with beer)
PB & J (Delicious :))

Environment is cute and cozy, inside Belden alley. Service is okay, our waiter was pretty sarcastic, I mean he was trying to be funny, but no one laughed, therefore we felt he was rude, but it is what it is. 

Will definitely come again to try their devil eggs and dinner selection!
author: Natalie L.

description: Went to this spot for admin day and it was really delicious and service was great.  Everyone enjoyed their meal.  Odd thing is on the booth part it kind of went down a bit that made me jump.  It's a small spot in belden Alley but good.  Bit pricey too.
author: Tasha D.

description: This is the cain of Restaurant where you always want to come back. Beautiful environment, great customer service and delicious food
author: Mr N.

description:
Sauce #SanFrancisco brings comfort food, with a choice of an indoor or outdoor vibe. European feel in Cali! 
#Foodie
author: andrew E.

description: Reminds me of a typical pub with simple dishes. I think the prices are a bit much for what they serve. I ordered a salmon filet which came on a bed of salad. Everything about the dish was over salted. There were pieces of salad that I cringed when eating because of the amount of salt on them. The salad was also drenched in some sort of dressing which made it disappointingly wilted. Also the sear on the filet was terrible. It was barely there as though they had been constantly flipping it in the pan. I ordered a raspberry gin drink that was good. The first drink was really good actually, but the second one was basically straight up gin. The atmosphere is a bit noisy but nothing crazy. The food and drinks are definitely not worth the cost. The service is amazing, though! My server was really kind and helpful.
author: Batya M.

description:
Came here with my bf post work and the mushroom fries were ON POINT. Parking was okay, and the margarita was pretty good! We got one margarita and one mojito, margarita was a lot better. Absolutely adored it!! Food came out fast. We also go scallop wrapped in bacon along with mac n cheese. For dessert we got mini smores, which was great too!! Loved the taste and flavor of this place. 

This place is tucked away in a little alley, but there is also a full size bar. Lots of people drop by for the bar, they do stop serving food earlier, so be sure to check in with them.
author: Amy Y.

description: My husband and I ate here for lunch during our stay and we loved it! We liked the "alleyway" feel and sat outside, it was a great day. Though the server was kind and food came out quick, we were left mainly to ourselves but we didn't mind. The food was delicious! I had the veggie burger that came with a salad and chips and it was just perfect. Best veggie burger, even for a non-vegetarian! I loved having a somewhat healthy lunch while still satisfying my fried food-loving appetite. My husband had the clam chowder which he thought was delicious. I'd say we'll definitely come back if we're in the area again!
author: Paige W.

description: The restaurant is located in very cute alley. The staff were very friendly and the food was pricey but yummy!
author: Shannon R.

description: Fabulous!!!  Crab roll is so much better than the lobster roll  BEYOND DELICIOUS.   We also tried the Cabernet on tap...... yes I know..... but WOW WOW WOW beyond words.  Will definitely be back, can't go wrong with this place and service is just as good as the food. .
author: Ali F.

description: We had a great time here last night. Great server, atmosphere and music. I had the vegetable pastry dish - which was delicious!!! I highly recommend this place
author: Susie D.

description:
My #tokenblackserver was like a mix of the dude from Kimmy Schmidt & the dude from Hunger Games. #funtimes You know I kept waiting for him to be like #byefelicia or tell me about electricity; sadly, it didn't happen. #thatswhatshesaid #nobromo

Rounding down to 3 stars bc price for what you get (my dindin = $72 pp), but location so #notfullytrippin. Kid nearby kept getting disciplined; mildly amusing at first #cookielyonsaid #whitepeopleproblems but got old. Kid should've put the headphones back on. #faceoff

(^_^) Lobster Roll $28 (http://bit.ly/1L8Lnld)
#atribecalledquestsaid Butter baby

(^_^) Iced Tea $3.25 (http://bit.ly/1hBKBT8)
Bitterish

(-_^) Bacon Mini Meatloaf $11 (http://bit.ly/1hBKAhX)
Meatballs #donttrustthebinapt23

(-_^) Mushroom Fries $11 (http://bit.ly/1L8LpJU)
Looks dry, but it's juicy. #thatswhatshesaid

Easy casual-yet-classyish ambience x food. May return someday to investigate the Mini Chicken Pot Pies and the Sirloin Steak. Happy Birthday(te) to the 2-top behind me. Did your wish come true with that chick, brah? ;p #butyousayshesjustafriend #butyousayshesjustafriend
author: Dan B.

description:
Ehhh I was pretty disappointed by this place (the service was atrocious, but the food is decent), but mostly, I was pretty embarrassed.  I came here a few weeks ago during lunch with a bunch of managers as a "thank you" as I put in my 2 week notice, so I wanted to take them out to lunch and this place had high marks.  Boy...the joke was on me.

We walked into the restaurant, and it was empty.  Well, almost empty, there was a bartender cleaning out some glasses but no hostess, no waitresses.  There was a party of 2 seated inside and at most 3 parties seated outside.  This was at 12 PM mind you, right during the lunch rush, but I'm not quite sure they got the memo.  Anyways, it was quite a few minutes before someone finally came by and seated us.

There's a good selection on the menu, particularly on the social plates.  The portobello mushroom fries is one of their specialty items and I think a must try.  Their house burger is also a good choice to go with.  

After waiting for our food, the server brought out 3 orders (we were a party of 5), and after setting our orders down, we all decided to wait until the remaining orders came.  It turns out, the server brought us the wrong orders!  So we ended up waiting for another 10-15 minutes for our order...I'm sure someone screwed up and had to remake our orders.  Mistakes happen, totally understandable...but not even a simple "We're sorry"..

Finally, as I was looking to pay the bill, our waitress disappeared!  I managed to flag down the waitress who was serving the table next to us, and after she had finished with the table's orders, I asked if she could get our waitress, and she replied "No, sorry I'm busy."  ...??!?!  

I would have considered giving this 3 stars, but after re-reading what I wrote and the fact that it was a lunch with mainly executives and managers, this place leaves a bad taste in my mouth. 

Explore other options in Belden Lane, there's a reason why this place was empty as it was during the lunch hour rush.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Late night gem!
We found this to be the closest open restaurant one night and were we happy we found it or what! 
So cute with its string lights, inside and outside seating, bar hang, small snacks or full dinner - it's up to you! 
The food was flawless and very nicely presented. I ordered the ham hock tater tots to share but ops, pretty much ate them all. They are served with ketchup, ok, and a green herb dipping sauce, wow!!My lobster bisque was perfect and also tried the Moscow Mule which was perfectly fine.
You will find me in this alley again for sure.
author: Camilla J.

description:
Oh how I love alleys! Especially if there's some good food to get as well.
Sauce - Belden is one of those places. While looking for a place to have lunch at (one of us wanted to have fries with 'something', the other was craving a sandwich, and another one was only interested in having drinks) in this pretty touristy area, I thank all Yelpers out there for sending me straight to Sauce - Belden.

We cheated and walked through Super Duper Burgers on Kearny St to get to Sauce - Belden (Tip!). This place has a nice intimate outdoor seating area. Keep that in mind for when the sun is out. The food we ordered (Bacon & Eggs and a Grilled chicken breast sandwich) was surprisingly good (the bacon is so good, I wonder it is made from a unicorn!), but including having drinks (at happy hour!) this lunch still ended up in quite a pricey pitstop before having dinner later on that day. 

Why 4 stars? I love to 'get away' from busy areas without actually leaving them. The location of Sauce - Belden is therefore just perfect!
author: Kirstin G.

description:
This review is solely for their social plates. 

My friend and I ate at the outside seating in Belden Place, which was a cute spot to catch up and dine together. We decided to share and only order social plates so we could have a little bit of everything.

Food was a bit pricey, but service was great, everything tasted distinct and delicious, and portion sizes were just right - perfect for two people! 

I loved that the food was given in even amounts, which made sharing easy and avoided that awkward "You should eat the last piece!" situation. 

OUR ORDERS:
- Deviled Eggs with Bacon
- Shrimp & Artichoke Wontons
- Portabello Mushroom Fries (my favorite)
- Mini Chicken Pot Pies
- Beef Tenderloin Carpaccio

Ordering the social plates is great if you're dining in groups because you can add variation to your meal and still get full from several appetizers. 

I was very impressed by how the food tasted and how they were presented. I would love to come back here again!
author: Kristal D.

description:
Wow! This place was amazing. My brother was visiting and it was super late, but we were able to find this place and have a spectacular late (11pm'ish) dinner. The food was perfectly prepared and good quantity. The meat was super tender and the spices were on point. 

We ordered two of the four desserts they offer and they were both perfectly prepared. Again, the quantity matched the quality and it was just enough for us to share both. 

I will most def come back here when in the area.
author: Nida K.

description: Went here for lunch and the food was outstanding. You definitely have to try the bowl of bacon. So good.
author: Fareedah S.

description:
Belden Place often feels like a tourist trap with restaurant greeters competing for your attention along the tiny alley and I've had bad food experiences to prove that hypothesis. 

While not amazing, Sauce provides consistently decent takes on American comfort food classics and in good portions. Come prepared to share appetizers like ham hock tater tots, bacon wrapped meatloaf, mushroom fries, and bacon deviled eggs. Not the place if you're looking for a light lunch. 

In terms of entrees, they make a decent, though unmemorable, bacon and cheese burger. The food coma-inducing fried chicken will make it a challenge to stay awake at work right after lunch. The chicken is crispy and the meat is moist although it could use more salt/seasoning. The highlight though was the creamed corn served in its husk. All up a heavy but satisfying meal. 

The Hayes Valley location is more intimate but this is livelier. Prices trend a little higher especially when compared with what you can get elsewhere in the same price range, but it's aligned with most spots in Belden. 4 stars perhaps is a stretch for Sauce but for consistency along Belden Place, we'll bump it up.
author: Jon L.

description:
Was skeptical about dining here. But it turned out great for a team dinner. The restaurant is super casual and great social plates and entrees. Good for a group of 18+ and they were flexible adjusting our table cos people flake.

Crab roll was good and fresher
We loved the bacon bowl
Meatloaf bacon wrap
Chicken potpie
Devil's egg
Shrimp Ceasar
Steak
Loved the PB&J dessert. Also tried s'mores and donuts but had better.

I thought chicken Pam was a miss. The meat was chewy and rubbery and lacked flavor.

Great service. Seating was all high top and bar like
author: Wendy K.

description:
I am amazed by the outdoor seating of Sauce. It reminds me so much of Europe! I came here with a coworker for my first day and it was a true surprise. I got their Lobster Roll lunch and it is amazing. The lobster roll is lightly butter and toasted with tons of fresh lobster meat. They also give you a side of fried chip with some interesting mayo dip and small salad. Overall, it is an amazing meal and for the price tag of $27, I think it is worth it! 

I heard they got great drinks too. Look forward to coming back and trying more food here.
author: Athena C.

description:
This is a 3.5 star rounded to a 4 star review.

I came here for lunch with coworkers, and we got some "outdoor seating" (under  a canopy right in an alleyway shared with 6 other restaurants). Despite feeling a little cramped, there was enough space to adjust seating and move around. 

I ordered the grilled akaushi kobe sirloin steak ($28), medium cooked. It consisted of 8 pieces of the Japanese red cow (akaushi) kobe steak, with fig, blue cheese, and pumpkin seeds on arugula with a side of potato skins. While I thought the salad would be perfect without the blue cheese, the main attraction here was the 8 pieces of steak, all of which were very tender and easy to chew, as expected. However, there were a couple of pieces that were more towards medium-rare, so while it would have been nice if it was a little consistent, I had no trouble finishing the dish. 

Service was significantly quicker than at Cafe Tiramisu, which is a definite plus! 
I'd love to come back here for dinner one of these days!
author: Viet N.

description:
I heard about this place from my coworkers who attend pretty regularly -- so I decided to check it out!  I love the location, right in the Financial District -- super easy to go after work.  But, what I really love is the super cute alley it's in!  It's located on Belden Street, and it's the cutest alley filled with restaurants (and if you go at night, it's filled with romantic hanging lights).

The waiting staff was very polite and courteous, however it did get busy and the service suffered quite a bit and we had to flag her down for water (not really a big deal to us).

I ordered the lobster roll and the lobster bisque -- and fair warning...I'm a native New Englander who moved to the Bay Area about a year and a half ago -- so I admit I can be a bit of a seafood snob with high standards.  I did not like the lobster bisque to be honest, the flavor was off, which was sad because I love lobster bisque!  The lobster roll was better than the bisque, but I wasn't really impressed either (a bit rubbery and stale tasting).  I WAS impressed by the plating -- all the food looked beautiful.  

So all in all, it's an adorable venue, the service is good, the food looks beautiful -- but it tastes a little disappointing.
author: Michelle S.

description: Love this place. Close to my office and I always manage to get a table even though they're always busy.  Outdoor seating is a great option when you're working in an office all day.  They have this candied bacon that is to die for. Served as an appetizer is so wonderful or as part of their delicious Cobb salad will leave you wanting more.  A bit on the noisy side but the food is well worth it.
author: Dennis R.

description:
Sauce Sauce Sauce, what more can I say. I've been here maybe 5 times within the last 2 months. This is close to my work and my go-to place to bring people. Happy Hour every weekday 2-6pm. 

Good drinks, great service, good food. LOVE their mushroom fries. The only reason I took a star off is because they took their beef stroganoff off the menu :(
author: Eve C.

description:
A cute place for catch session! I would definitely make reservations if you can. There is a variety of food to choose from, a little pricey for some stuff. 

I got the mushroom fries, chicken pot pie, and the vegetarian strudel. Everybody raved about the fries, but I found them okay. 

I would definitely recommend the vegetarian strudel. The flavors are there and you will not be disappointed.
author: Jackie N.

description: We went in pretty late, around 10pm as it was one of the few places open at Belden place. But I swear, I've never had a better salmon in my life. I probably asked each attendant that served us to convey my best to the chef.
author: Mayank S.

description: Great lunch spot tucked away on Belden street with some modern takes on American cuisine (e.g. Portobello fries). I usually go with the salmon and it's predictably good. The chili will also warm your heart up. The vibe and service are good, but not the best in the area. Good for a quick drink after work or lunch, not the best food in the area for a nice dinner.
author: Barron C.

description:
Good food & happy hour menu! We came at about 6:30 on a Friday. We didn't have reservations, but there were plenty of tables. It's in this cute European-esque alley full of restaurants.

They had a great happy hour deal of a Moscow mule and 2 sliders for $12, but the rest of the menu looked much more interesting than sliders, so I just got the Moscow mule by itself (which was good, nice and gingery), and then we shared three small plates:

BOWL OF BACON: candied, and just as delicious as you'd expect. Get this.

MINI CHICKEN POT PIES: Good! Juicy, but not overly messy. Roughly two bites/piece, comes with 4  pieces.

PORTOBELLO MUSHROOM FRIES: When I read this, I expected it to be French fries served with mushrooms on top, but it's actually fried sticks of mushrooms - which was great! These were yummy.

Service was very fast and friendly.
author: Liz F.

description: Came here for lunch with my cousin. After a long walk from the Ferry Building we decided to check out Sauce. I ordered the chicken sandwich and my cousin had the Black Bean and lentel sandwich. Forgot to take a picture of our food when it came out but the presentation was not disappointing. My sandwich was very tasty as well as my cousin's sandwich.  All sandwiches come with a side salad and home made spicy chips. I will definitely make a trip to Sauce again when visiting San Francisco.
author: Norma L.

description:
Welcoming a new Department Head & celebrating out of town coworkers, we had chosen Sauce as our vehicle by which to commence the cheer & team bonding

Happy Hour drinkys ranged from assorted wines which were all deemed delish to my choice of the Moscow Mule

Served in the requisite copper mug, this was a dangerously scrumptious drink - vodka, lime, ginger beer.....YUM!  But be warned, that Mule will kick your a**!  I was totally giddy by the time we left.....

Plates of shares appies also found their way to the table & there is a huge focus on bacon at Sauce.  The crowd had the ham hock tater tots, bowl of bacon, deviled eggs w/ bacon & portobello fries that may or may not have had some kind of bacon dipping sauce ( I obviously did not partake but can say the plates were cleaned super fast )

The cheese plate was totally skimpy & you should be ashamed to serve such small, almost transparent, slivers of cheese - skip this!!

Luckily the team also ordered a Mac N Cheese without bacon - this mac n cheese was eye rolling-ly good!  Thick pasta shells with a ton of creamy, cheesy, bechamel & cheddar melted on top and let's not forget the breadcrumbs.  SO GOOD!

The server also told us they offer a veggie burger that's not on the menu & I'm SO coming back for that burger w/ a side of mac n cheese of course!!  Yup, we'll be back....soon!!!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
They have a decent Happy Hour with a nice selection of draft beers and wine from the barrel.  I ended up having the lobster roll with fries.   (Fries, instead of chips are worth the upcharge because they were battered deep-fried goodness.  You're welcome.)  

We also shared the Portobello mushroom fries for the table.  They were ok.  My colleagues both ended up with the chili and seemed to enjoy it thoroughly.
author: Patricia N.

description:
It looked like a small plates kind of place, but the portions were actually nicely sized, and really rather delicious. I had the bacon-wrapped meatloaf, which came out much better than expected, accompanied by sides of mushroom fries and mac and cheese, both of which were very well-done. 

I was very pleasantly surprised by this restaurant.
author: John L.

description: I wanted to write something more in depth than just bacon... But bacon bacon bacon bacon... Dear god BACON!
author: Nathan D.

description:
Came here for a last minute date night! What a perfect way to end our Saturday night. So many good things to say about this place!  

First of all, it's fantastic that they're open until 1:00 am. No need to settle for a fast food joint, come here late night for quality food. 

Our server, Deon was very friendly and helped us decide on our orders. Sirloin Steak, Chicken Parmesan, and Chicken Pot Pies. No regrets!

Sirloin- The sauce complimented the sirloin really well. Not too overwhelming. Not too salty, too sweet. It doesn't take away from the flavor of the steak like you might expect. Cooked medium, the texture was perfect. Juicy and oh so tender! Served with garlic Parmesan potatoes, and sautéed spinach and kale.

Chicken Parmesan- Thin crisp layer with juicy chicken thigh. Served with arugala salad. The salad was somewhat tangy, it went well with the chicken Parmesan! Such a perfect plate it was amazing to the palette! 

Chicken Pot Pies- Very good pie crust. 

Great bar area if you want to have some drinks also!

Kind of pricey, but, it was worth it for the ambiance, food, and service! We'll be coming back some time again :)
author: Stephanie D.

description:
We dined here during SF Restaurant week in January and I was pleasantly surprised to find Sauce located in a narrow dimly lit alley surrounded by a few other restaurants in the FiDi. We all went with the Prix Fixe menu as the choices sounded savory.

The excellent Portobello Fries(normal menu item) was crispy on the outside and meaty on the inside. The Pork appetizer had nice contrast of soft and crunchy, however the highlight was definitely the Steak and Crab entree. Our meal was finished off with a light mini cherry pie with a scoop of pumpkin ice cream.

By nature of the location and restaurant setup, this can be a cozy, romantic spot to wine and dine that special someone in your life. Service was warm and spot on and after one visit, Sauce is a solid 4 stars in my book.
author: Dennis W.

description:
My date wanted to go to Belden Place. Honestly, the area feels a little touristy/kitschy for me. Out of the restaurants in this area, Sauce seemed to be the most promising. We were seated awkwardly along the walkway but luckily I was right under the heater and we were intoxicated enough not to care what else was happening nearby.

I had a Moscow Mule, which was served in a copper mug. It was actually quite good. I ordered the Grilled Akaushi Kobe Sirloin Steak and asked for it to be cooked medium rare. It came out medium to medium-well. The potato skins that accompanied the steak were better than the steak itself.

My date had a bowl of New England Seafood Chowder and Garlic Bread. The chowder was good but it wasn't the best I've had. The Garlic Bread, though, was cheesy and fabulous. That was the clear star of the entire meal.
author: Yi Z.

description: Came here for an intern lunch and found it to be tasty, but not worth the price. To be fair though, it probably is one of the better restaurants at Belden. All of us got the steak, which came out with four slices on a pile of greens with roasted buttered potatoes. The potatoes were crisp with creamy centers, pairing well with the steak and greens, which were quite flavorful but perhaps a little too salty. Good tasting food, but I feel like $28 could be better spent elsewhere, even in the financial district.
author: Hali M.

description:
This place surprised me with how good the food was. Not sure it should have been that way. But it happened. It's tasty. The place looks unlike its counterparts nearby. More of a bar look than a place you have a date or bring your family. Not bad, just more bar-like. The drinks flow and are pretty well-priced. But the food was the hit. Get the portobello fries!!!

Shout to our waiter and the staff in general, smiles all around. Great time at Sauce.
author: Josh M.

description:
Sauce is located in an alley lined with restaurants and as I was walking in to be seated, I couldn't help feel like this was a nicely kept secret in the Financial District. We dined here during SF Restaurant Week and the Prix Fixe menu looked appetizing and intriguing which isn't always the case with the previously named SF Dine About Town options.

I went with the Pork Appetizer(Pancetta wrapped pork with crispy sweet potato), and the Steak & Crab Entree(Peppered NY Steak, Yukon Au Gratin, Dungeness Crab, Mushrooms, Asparagus) and finished off with the Cherry Pie(Mini fried cherry pie with pumpkin ice cream). Everything was delish, and my tummy was definitely satisfied. 

Our waitress was friendly and service was attentive and quick. Just a warning, If you sit along the row of 3 tables underneath the ceiling heat lamps you may get a little too toasty warm.

In my many years of trying new restaurants through this program, I have to say the quality, and value that Sauce is offering this year is well above average and based on my one experience, I would definitely come back to try their other items.
author: Angela L.

description:
I'm realizing a strangely discomfiting pattern that has taken place over the decade I've been Yelping, and that is I am slowly eating my way down Belden Place. Really slowly. Like an average of every seventeen months. I must not be all that motivated, and then there's those women cajoling you to come into their restaurants. They could learn a lesson in subtlety from the Red Light window hookers in Amsterdam.
